column3: which said it based the article on more than 50 interviews

column7: the newspaper said.""A lot of things get made up over the years
column8: Trump told the Times. ""I have always treated women with great respect.""A Trump representative did not immediately respond to a request by Reuters for comment.Barbara Res
column9: who oversaw construction of Trump's Manhattan business headquarters
column10: said he would sometimes interrupt meetings with comments about women's figures. During a job interview for a Los Angeles project

column4: Res

column1: 3	3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-nordic-summit-idUSKCN0Y409Q	Obama toasts Nordic nations after Russia-focused summit	"
By Roberta Rampton and Jeff Mason
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON President Barack Obama toasted Sweden
column2: Denmark
column3: Finland
column4: Norway and Iceland at a star-studded state dinner on Friday
column5: lauding the nations for their global influence on civil rights
column6: humanitarian issues and curbing climate change.The red carpet glamor followed a White House summit where Obama and the leaders of the five nations presented a united front against Moscow's recent military aggression in Ukraine and the Baltic region.But the meeting was more about soft diplomacy than launching ambitious foreign policy endeavors
column7: given that Obama's second and final term ends in January. Americans will vote in presidential elections on Nov. 8.""I thought this was a very useful and important conversation
column8: although there was probably too much agreement to make for as exciting a multilateral meeting as I sometimes participate in
column9: Obama said.More than 300 guests including rapper Common
column10: comedian Will Farrell and actress Tracee Ellis Ross mingled with diplomats
column13: and political donors in a glass-ceiling tent built around a tree on the South Lawn.Hand-rolled beeswax candles and strings of lights reflected off ten-foot pillars of ice
column14: an homage to the northern lights.Pop star Demi Lovato
column15: known for her support of liberal causes
column16: was set to perform after a Nordic-inspired meal of ahi tuna
column17: tomato tartare and red wine-braised beef short ribs.

column1: It's a great opportunity to drink wine and make progress on the most serious issues of our time
column2: Samantha Power
column3: the U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations
column4: told reporters on her way into the dinner.RUSSIA

column1: The summit was aimed in part at sending a message to a nation not on the guest list: Russia
column2: which annexed Ukraine's Crimea region in 2014 and has stepped up its military posture.The North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) is planning its biggest build-up in eastern Europe since the Cold War to try to deter further Russian aggression
column3: and Denmark and Norway said on Friday they would contribute to the ""enhanced allied forward presence"" with NATO.""We will be maintaining ongoing dialogue and seek cooperation with Russia
column4: but we also want to make sure that we are prepared and strong
column5: and we want to encourage Russia to keep its military activities in full compliance with international obligations
column6: Obama said after the summit.Obama has long expressed admiration for the pragmatic and liberal-leaning politics of the Nordic nations.

column1: There have been times where I've said

column1: 6	6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-lgbt-idUSKCN0Y403J	U.S. tells schools to give transgender students bathroom rights	"
By Megan Cassella
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON The Obama administration told U.S. public schools on Friday that transgender students must be allowed to use the bathroom of their choice
column2: upsetting Republicans and raising the likelihood of fights over federal funding and legal authority. Conservatives pushed back against the administration's non-binding guidance to schools
column3: the latest battleground in the issue of rights for lesbian
column4: gay
column5: bisexual and transgender Americans. Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton said the guidance ""must be challenged.""""If President Obama thinks he can bully Texas schools into allowing men to have open access to girls in bathrooms
column6: he better prepare for yet another legal fight
column9: said in a statement.Other Republican-led states joined calls to disregard the White House's directive and accused the administration of overstepping its role. In North Carolina
column10: Governor Pat McCrory labeled the move a ""massive executive branch overreach"" and called on federal courts and the U.S. Congress to intercede
column11: while Arkansas Governor Asa Hutchinson said it was ""offensive
column12: intrusive and totally lacking in common sense.""The U.S. Education and Justice Departments
column14: told school districts nationwide that while the guidance carries no legal weight
column15: they must not discriminate against students
column16: including based on their gender identity.The guidance contained an implicit threat that school districts defying the Obama administration's interpretation of the law could face lawsuits or be deprived of federal aid.

column1: The White House defended its actions
column2: saying the guidance should not be viewed as a threat but instead as a set of ""specific
column3: tangible
column4: real-world advice and suggestions"" that many schools had sought and will welcome.""That's what we're looking for: solutions that protect the safety and dignity of every single student in school
column5: White House spokesman Josh Earnest told reporters at a daily briefing
column6: adding that the idea was to prevent discrimination against a range of groups extending beyond the transgender community.   The directive came as the Justice Department and North Carolina are battling in federal court over a North Carolina state law approved in March that prohibits people from using public restrooms not corresponding to their gender assigned at birth
column7: while other states weigh similar measures.North Carolina's law was the first to ban people from restrooms in public buildings and schools not matching the sex on their birth certificate. Mississippi has enacted legislation similarly viewed as discriminatory by civil and gay rights groups
column8: and Tennessee and Missouri considered similar measures.

column1: The letter to the schools from Washington said that
column2: to get federal funding under existing rules
column3: a school has to agree not to treat students or activities differently on the basis of sex. That includes not treating a transgender student differently from other students of the same gender identity
column4: officials said.The American Civil Liberties Union said the guidance would help make students ""free to bring their whole selves to school.""In a sign of what defiant states may face
column5: the Justice Department this week asked a U.S. District Court in North Carolina to declare the state in violation of the 1964 Civil Rights Act and order it to stop enforcing the ban.

column1: Americans are divided over which public restrooms should be used by transgender people
column2: a Reuters/Ipsos poll showed
column3: with 44 percent saying people should use them according to their biological sex and 39 percent saying they should be used according to the gender with which they identify.A group representing U.S. school boards called the guidance ""unsettled law.""""A dispute about the intent of the federal law must ultimately be resolved by the courts and the Congress
column4: the National School Boards Association said in a statement. Donald Trump
column5: the presumptive Republican presidential nominee
column6: was less critical than many of his party in several television interviews
column7: saying the issue should be left up to individual states. ""Everybody has to be protected ... but it's a tiny
column9: Trump told Fox News. (Reporting by Megan Cassella and Susan Heavey; Additional reporting by Roberta Rampton in Washington
column10: Colleen Jenkins in Winston-Salem and Jon Herskovitz in Austin; Editing by Frances Kerry

column1: 7	7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKCN0Y41PM	Trump taps climate change skeptic as energy adviser
column2: pushes back on taxes	"

column1: By Valerie Volcovici and Emily Flitter
| WASHINGTON/NEW YORK

WASHINGTON/NEW YORK Donald Trump on Friday picked a prominent climate change skeptic to help him craft his energy policy and pushed back against renewed calls that he release his income tax returns - saying his tax rate is ""none of your business.""The presumptive Republican presidential nominee is seeking to build out his policy proposals as he pivots from campaigning for his party's nomination to a likely general election matchup with Democratic rival Hillary Clinton.Among those he has asked for help is U.S. Republican Representative Kevin Cramer of North Dakota
column2: one of the country's most ardent oil and gas drilling advocates and climate change skeptics. North Dakota has been at the forefront of the U.S. shale oil and gas boom. Trump's team asked Cramer
column3: who has endorsed Trump
column4: to write a white paper
column5: or detailed report
column7: according to Cramer and sources familiar with the matter.Cramer said in an interview that his white paper would emphasize the dangers of foreign ownership of U.S. energy assets
column8: as well as what he characterized as burdensome taxes and over-regulation. Trump will have an opportunity to float some of the ideas at an energy summit in Bismarck
column10: Cramer said.    The senator was also among a group of Trump advisers who recently met with lawmakers from Western energy states
column11: who hope Trump will open more federal land for drilling
column12: a lawmaker who took part in the meeting said.A spokeswoman for Trump's campaign did not comment.Environmental groups
column14: quickly attacked Trump for tapping Cramer.""Kevin Cramer has consistently backed reckless and dangerous schemes to put the profits of fossil fuel executives before the health of the public
column15: so he and Trump are a match made in polluter heaven
column16: Sierra Club Legislative Director Melinda Pierce said in an emailed statement.The Clinton campaign also criticized the move.

column1: Donald Trump's choice of outspoken climate (change) denier Kevin Cramer to advise him on energy policy is just the latest piece of evidence that letting him get near the White House would put our children's health and futures at risk
column2: said campaign spokesman Jesse Ferguson.Trump has been light on the details of his energy policy
column3: though he recently told supporters in West Virginia that the coal industry would thrive if he were president. He has also claimed global warming is a concept ""created by and for the Chinese"" to hurt U.S. business.Clinton
column4: meanwhile
column5: has advocated shifting the country to 50 percent clean energy by 2030
column7: and said her prospective administration would put coal companies ""out of business.""'NONE OF YOUR BUSINESS'

column1: Trump also took heat on Friday for not releasing his tax returns
column2: something that American presidential candidates have done for decades. Clinton and her rival
column3: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont
column4: have both released their returns.Trump has said the Internal Revenue Service was auditing his returns and he wanted to wait until the review was over before making them public. ""It should be
column5: and I hope it's before the election
column6: Trump told ABC's ""Good Morning America.""Pressed on what tax rate he pays
column7: Trump refused to say. ""It's none of your business
column8: he said. The candidate has said there is nothing voters can learn from his tax filings. Tax filings show sources of income
column9: both from within the United States and other countries
column12: deductions and other financial information.The IRS declined to comment on whether Trump or any other presidential candidates were being audited.

column1: However
column2: the Trump campaign earlier this year released a letter from his attorneys saying his personal tax returns have been under ""continuous examination"" from the IRS.This week
column3: Clinton began calling on her probable Republican rival to release his returns. Last August
column4: the former U.S. secretary of state posted the past eight years of tax returns for her and her husband
column5: former President Bill Clinton
column6: on her website. Sanders released his 2014 return in April. Presidential candidates have a long history in the modern era of releasing their tax returns.""In 1976
column7: Gerald Ford did not release his returns
column8: but he did release some information about his taxes
column10: director of the Tax History Project at Tax Analysts
column12: nonpartisan group that provides tax news and analysis.""That was the last time that a major party nominee hasn't done it
column14: previous WASHINGTON.)     (Reporting by Megan Cassella and Susan Heavey; Writing by Luciana Lopez; Editing by Jonathan Oatis and Richard Valdmanis)"	['Sanders'

column1: 8	8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-fundraising-rally-idUSKCN0Y42KI	First $200 admission for a Trump rally; more to come?	"
By Emily Flitter
| NEW YORK

NEW YORK The email Donald Trump's campaign sent inviting fans to a rally next week looked familiar: ""Meet me in New Jersey!"" it urged. But something was different.""You will need to buy a ticket to get into the rally
column2: it added. The cost: $200.During the months-long battle for the Republican presidential nomination
column3: rallies staged by Trump
column4: the party's likely candidate in the Nov. 8 election
column5: were free and open to anyone with the stamina to withstand half a day's wait outside and a heady hour packed into a sports stadium or warehouse. Supporters could buy snacks or hats or T-shirts while they waited
column6: but they never had to pay for admission.The May 19 rally advertised in the email is a fundraiser for New Jersey Governor Chris Christie
column7: a former presidential rival now working for Trump who
column9: needs to retire debt from his own failed campaign. The emailed invitation to supporters said it will be a fundraiser. It was not clear whether Trump will charge for rallies that are not specifically designated as fundraisers.

column1: The New York billionaire has claimed he was self-funding his campaign and did not need donations. He has financed his offensive in the nominating phase of the race for the White House with loans to himself as well as around $12 million in unsolicited donations from fans.Now that Trump is pivoting toward the general election
column2: where conventional estimates put the cost of winning at around $1 billion
column3: things are changing. The move to charge admission for some appearances was just one harbinger of a new relationship between Trump and his fans
column4: many of whom cited their perception of his financial independence as a major factor behind their support. It will test the loyalty of those who have swelled his rallies to capacity
column5: either transforming huge crowds into cash cows or creating more breathing room in the places where he appears.

column1: When asked whether the format of the Christie fundraiser rally would be repeated in the future
column2: Trump's spokeswoman
column3: Hope Hicks
column4: did not comment. ""This is a fundraiser for Governor Christie
column5: she said.Supporters have said Trump's about-face on fundraising does not bother them.

column1: Susan Kihne
column2: a Mandan
column3: North Dakota resident who snagged a ticket to see Trump speak at a petroleum conference later this month decided the $30 it cost her was worth it.""He's self-funded up until now
column4: so I don't mind supporting him
column5: she said. (Reporting By Emily Flitter; Additional reporting by Michelle Conlin; Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"	['Trump'
